elements.title: Japanese mountain cherry (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that bears may be dispersers of the Japanese mountain cherry (painting pictured)?

elements.title: Philomena Franz (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Romani Holocaust survivor Philomena Franz wrote about her deportation to Auschwitz, internment in Ravensbrück, escape from a camp near Wittenberge, and concealment by a farmer?

elements.title: a large basin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a large basin on Neptune's moon Triton may have once been filled with liquid water cryolava, similar to how liquid silicates fill lava lakes on Earth?

elements.title: Inman Jackson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Inman Jackson played "as though he were born with a basketball in each hand"?

elements.title: Josephine Kenyon (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Josephine Kenyon moved from recommendations of rigid scheduling to "on-demand" scheduling in editions of her book Healthy Babies Are Happy Babies?

elements.title: Amie Parnes (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Amie Parnes allegedly first heard about her employer, The Messenger, ceasing operations from a New York Times article?

elements.title: Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly was released after the main creator of Coffee Talk died in March 2022?

elements.title: Liviu Holender (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that baritone Liviu Holender chose lieder by five composers whose music was banned by the Nazis—Schreker, Zemlinsky, Mahler, Korngold and Schönberg—for a recital at the Oper Frankfurt?

elements.title: Estoppey D-8 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that some members of the U.S. Army Air Corps were so unimpressed by the Estoppey D-8 that one member stated that he would rather use "nails and a wire"?
